s.text: !! Here we have an able-bodied, selfish caffeine addict, who can't seem to wait for a stall, callously making someone who is handicapped wait.
Let me enlighten you: Almost every time I need to use the disabled stall (I am in a wheelchair), I have to wait for an AB to leave, and they all apologize meekly when they leave.
!! Here we have an able-bodied, selfish caffeine addict, who can't seem to wait for a stall, callously making someone who is handicapped wait.
However, the comment I object to is the one where you say there is never a handicapped person waiting to use it when you are done.
Prudie, herself, after undergoing some rather strong e-mail aversion therapy, plans never to step foot in the more spacious stall again.
One is that the disabled have a strong, perhaps disproportionate, influence when it comes to public policy.
An illogical example of the power of this lobby can be found in hospitals.
Following is a fair sampling from the deluge, with Prudie's thoughts at the end.
Following is a fair sampling from the deluge, with Prudie's thoughts at the end.
